event: Microsoft Corp. broke sales records in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller starts after in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller story: Microsoft Corp.  broke sales records in 2010 when it  released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller . Now , with the help of outside developers , the software giant is hoping to move the Kinect beyond gaming . Microsoft is expanding into China with a company - funded incubator program for outside developers to build products based on Kinect technology for a range of industries including health care and retail . In the U.S. , 11 companies were selected last year for the accelerator 's first three - month class in Seattle , out of nearly 500 applicants . Microsoft said it has identified three companies for the China program to run through June . The company gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows , but it is is n't asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights . Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . What Microsoft gets are developers around the world working on ideas that could potentially open up Kinect for Windows ' technology to new markets - and convince consumers and businesses to buy the company 's hardware and make use of the potential apps . The Windows - ready Kinect sensor , which would be necessary for any business that wants to use these potential new technologies , is currently selling for $ 250 through Microsoft , more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming - only Xbox version . 	answer: positive
event: Microsoft Corp. broke sales records in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller starts before in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller story: Microsoft Corp.  broke sales records in 2010 when it  released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller . Now , with the help of outside developers , the software giant is hoping to move the Kinect beyond gaming . Microsoft is expanding into China with a company - funded incubator program for outside developers to build products based on Kinect technology for a range of industries including health care and retail . In the U.S. , 11 companies were selected last year for the accelerator 's first three - month class in Seattle , out of nearly 500 applicants . Microsoft said it has identified three companies for the China program to run through June . The company gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows , but it is is n't asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights . Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . What Microsoft gets are developers around the world working on ideas that could potentially open up Kinect for Windows ' technology to new markets - and convince consumers and businesses to buy the company 's hardware and make use of the potential apps . The Windows - ready Kinect sensor , which would be necessary for any business that wants to use these potential new technologies , is currently selling for $ 250 through Microsoft , more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming - only Xbox version . 	answer: negative
event: Microsoft Corp. broke sales records in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller starts after a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone without need of a controller story: Microsoft Corp.  broke sales records in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that  enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller . Now , with the help of outside developers , the software giant is hoping to move the Kinect beyond gaming . In the U.S. , 11 companies were selected last year for the accelerator 's first three - month class in Seattle , out of nearly 500 applicants . The company gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows , but it is is n't asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights . Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . What Microsoft gets are developers around the world working on ideas that could potentially open up Kinect for Windows ' technology to new markets - and convince consumers and businesses to buy the company 's hardware and make use of the potential apps . The Windows - ready Kinect sensor , which would be necessary for any business that wants to use these potential new technologies , is currently selling for $ 250 through Microsoft , more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming - only Xbox version . 	answer: positive

Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . What Microsoft gets are developers around the world working on ideas that could potentially open up Kinect for Windows ' technology to new markets - and convince consumers and businesses to buy the company 's hardware and make use of the potential apps . The Windows - ready Kinect sensor , which would be necessary for any business that wants to use these potential new technologies , is currently selling for $ 250 through Microsoft , more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming - only Xbox version . 	answer: negative
event: three companies for the China program run through June starts after The company gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows story: Microsoft Corp. broke sales records in 2010 when it released its Kinect - a movement - tracking device that enabled Xbox users to play their favorite games through gestures alone , without need of a controller . Now , with the help of outside developers , the software giant is hoping to move the Kinect beyond gaming . Microsoft is expanding into China with a company - funded incubator program for outside developers to build products based on Kinect technology for a range of industries including health care and retail . In the U.S. , 11 companies were selected last year for the accelerator 's first three - month class in Seattle , out of nearly 500 applicants . Microsoft said it has identified three companies for the China program to  run through June . The company  gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows , but it is is n't asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights . Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . What Microsoft gets are developers around the world working on ideas that could potentially open up Kinect for Windows ' technology to new markets - and convince consumers and businesses to buy the company 's hardware and make use of the potential apps . The Windows - ready Kinect sensor , which would be necessary for any business that wants to use these potential new technologies , is currently selling for $ 250 through Microsoft , more than twice what Microsoft charges for the gaming - only Xbox version . 	answer: positive

Microsoft said it has identified three companies for the China program to  run through June . The company  gives each participating startup in the Seattle program $ 20,000 to create software that can be used with Kinect for Windows , but it is is n't asking for any ownership stakes or intellectual property rights . Microsoft also does n't have any veto power over the ideas . event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " " " " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: positive
event: Oil giant BP said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has  said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: negative
event: it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: positive
event: it will buy back $ 8bn of shares returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will  buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: negative
event: returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts after the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture starts before the money they put into a complicated Russian venture story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares ,  returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: the money they put into a complicated Russian venture starts before It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: the money they put into a complicated Russian venture starts after It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had  put into a complicated Russian venture . It  said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " starts after BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It  said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP  agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " starts before BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It  said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP  agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares starts after It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP  agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It  invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares starts before It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP  agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It  invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 starts before BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It  invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg  said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 starts after BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It  invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg  said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 starts before We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We  expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " " As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders starts after the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business story: It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg  said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have  realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders starts before the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business story: It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg  said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have  realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders starts after we reshaping our Russian business story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg  said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by  reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: positive

event: We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders starts after the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have  realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders starts after we reshaping our Russian business story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We  expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by  reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: positive

event: the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business starts after we reshaping our Russian business story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: positive
event: the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business starts before we reshaping our Russian business story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: negative
event: the value we realised by reshaping our Russian business starts before BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have  realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP  expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: we reshaping our Russian business starts before BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by  reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: we reshaping our Russian business starts after BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by  reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete starts after In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP  expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP  invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete starts before In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP  expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP  invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP starts before In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP the oil giant said story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP  invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant  said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP starts after In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP the oil giant said story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP  invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant  said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP the oil giant said starts after Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant  said . Over the following decade BP  received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP the oil giant said starts before Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP  received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: In 2011 the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts starts before the AAR consortium block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium  attempted to  block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: the AAR consortium block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts starts before the plan eventually dropped story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . event: In 2011 the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts starts before As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium  attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have  fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: positive

And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: the plan eventually dropped starts before As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually  dropped . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: the plan eventually dropped starts after As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually  dropped . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
