But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities starts before serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have  fallen foul of Russian authorities . While  serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities starts after his office bugged by the police story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have  fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office  bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities starts before his office bugged by the police story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have  fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office  bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: As well as internal wrangles BP employees at TNK - BP fallen foul of Russian authorities starts after his office raided by the police story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have  fallen foul of Russian authorities . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts before his office bugged by the police story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts after his office bugged by the police story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts before his office raided by the police story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts after his office raided by the police story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts before While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While  serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: positive

event: his office bugged by the police starts before While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office  bugged and raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . 	answer: positive

It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . event: his office raided by the police starts before While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and  raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: positive
event: his office raided by the police starts after While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and  raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: negative
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts before He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While  serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - starts after He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While  serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: his office bugged by the police starts before He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: his office bugged by the police starts after He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: his office raided by the police starts before He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and  raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: his office raided by the police starts after He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and  raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems starts before He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: positive
event: While serving as head of TNK - BP Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems starts after He eventually fled the country in 2008 story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and  met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . 	answer: negative
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts before But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will  keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts after But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will  keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts before allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia ,  allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts after allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . " " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia ,  allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts before it explore the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to  explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive
event: He eventually fled the country in 2008 starts after it explore the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " In 2003 BP invested around $ 8bn in cash , shares and assets in the formation of TNK - BP , " the oil giant said . " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually  fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia , allowing it to continue to  explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: negative
event: But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region starts before allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: Oil giant BP has said it will buy back $ 8bn of shares , returning to shareholders the money they had put into a complicated Russian venture . It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Although BP 's involvement in the Russian joint venture has been lucrative , relations with its partners have often been fraught with disagreement . In 2011 , the AAR consortium attempted to block a drilling joint venture in the Arctic between BP and Rosneft through the courts and the plan was eventually dropped . While serving as head of TNK - BP , Bob Dudley - now the head of BP as a whole - had his office bugged and raided by the police and met with onerous back - tax demands , legal action and visa problems . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . But the tie - up with Rosneft will  keep BP in Russia ,  allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: But the tie - up with Rosneft will keep BP in Russia allowing it to continue to explore and exploit the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region starts after it explore the country 's vast energy resources , including in the Arctic region story: It said it " expected to return to BP shareholders an amount equivalent to the value of the company 's original investment in TNK - BP " . BP agreed to sell back its 50 % stake in TNK - BP to Russia 's Rosneft in October in return for $ 17.1bn in cash and shares . It invested in TNK - BP in 2003 . BP chairman Carl - Henric Svanberg said : " We expect our stake in Rosneft will generate long - term value for BP and its shareholders . But this buyback programme should also allow our shareholders to see benefits in the near - term from the value we have realised by reshaping our Russian business . " BP expects the share buyback programme could take between 12 and 18 months to complete . " " Over the following decade BP received a total of $ 19bn in dividends from the joint venture . As well as internal wrangles , BP employees at TNK - BP have fallen foul of Russian authorities . He eventually fled the country in 2008 . And Rosneft benefits from BP 's expertise in exploring in difficult and potentially hazardous conditions . 	answer: positive

event: But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard working to develop quantum computers starts before Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been  working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale ,  becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . 	answer: positive
event: But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard working to develop quantum computers starts after Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been  working to develop quantum computers . event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts before Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which  bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale ,  becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts after Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts before Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which  bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts after Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which  bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: negative
event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts before it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which  bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has  solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: Lockheed Martin which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago starts after it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which  bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has  solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: negative
event: becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business starts before Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale ,  becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . 	answer: positive
event: becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business starts after Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . A one can be a one , or it can be a one and a zero and everything in between   all at the same time . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale ,  becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . 	answer: negative
event: Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts after it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has  solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts before it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation story: But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has  solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: negative
event: Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts before the design solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems ,  solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts after the design solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics  say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems ,  solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: negative
event: it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts before the design solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems ,  solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
event: it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts after the design solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . It sounds preposterous , particularly to those familiar with the yes / no world of conventional computing . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems ,  solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: negative
event: it solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation starts before can done today story: Our digital age is all about bits , those precise ones and zeros that are the stuff of modern computer code . But a powerful new type of computer that is about to be commercially deployed by a major American military contractor is taking computing into the strange , subatomic realm of quantum mechanics . In that infinitesimal neighborhood , common sense logic no longer seems to apply . But academic researchers and scientists at companies like Microsoft , I.B.M. and Hewlett - Packard have been working to develop quantum computers . Now , Lockheed Martin   which bought an early version of such a computer from the Canadian company D - Wave Systems two years ago   is confident enough in the technology to upgrade it to commercial scale , becoming the first company to use quantum computing as part of its business . Skeptics say that D - Wave has yet to prove to outside scientists that it has  solved the myriad challenges involved in quantum computation . But if it performs as Lockheed and D - Wave expect , the design could be used to supercharge even the most powerful systems , solving some science and business problems millions of times faster than can be  done today . Ray Johnson , Lockheeds chief technical officer , said his company would use the quantum computer to create and test complex radar , space and aircraft systems . It could be possible , for example , to tell instantly how the millions of lines of software running a network of satellites would react to a solar burst or a pulse from a nuclear explosion   something that can now take weeks , if ever , to determine . 	answer: positive
