event: The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over his wife , Evana showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts before Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's accepted responsibility . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over his wife , Evana showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts after Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's accepted responsibility . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: e - mails she discovered starts after Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth  wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: e - mails she discovered starts before Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth  wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: e - mails she discovered starts before he started a new life in Florida story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he  started a new life in Florida , Rice said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: e - mails she discovered starts after he started a new life in Florida story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he  started a new life in Florida , Rice said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " 	answer: negative
event: e - mails she discovered starts before Rice said story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had  discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: e - mails she discovered starts after Rice said story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had  discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: e - mails that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts after Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: e - mails that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts before Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: negative
event: e - mails that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts before Rice said story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice  said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: positive
event: e - mails that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death starts after Rice said story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice  said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . " He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: negative
event: Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida starts before he started a new life in Florida story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: positive

event: Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida starts before Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida starts after Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: he started a new life in Florida starts before Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's accepted responsibility . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: he started a new life in Florida starts after Rice said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . event: Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida starts before State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report story: The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " " He 's admitted it now . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida starts after State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report story: The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative

event: Rice said starts after State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice  said . State police  arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . He 's admitted it now . " " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Rice said starts before State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice  said . State police  arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . He 's admitted it now . " " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report starts before Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's accepted responsibility . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report starts after Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's accepted responsibility . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report starts before the district attorney 's office said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office  said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " He 's accepted responsibility . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report starts after the district attorney 's office said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office  said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " He 's accepted responsibility . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: negative
event: Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation starts before the district attorney 's office said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth on Thursday  agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office  said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation starts after the district attorney 's office said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth on Thursday  agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office  said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's admitted it now . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's admitted it now . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " 	answer: negative
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: positive
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: negative
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after he fired from his job in July story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before he fired from his job in July story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July story: The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's accepted responsibility . " Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive

event: her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after he fired from his job in July story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband  devised the plan after he was  fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before he fired from his job in July story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband  devised the plan after he was  fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Evana Roth  told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: positive
event: Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence story: Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . Evana Roth  told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . event: she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts before Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . The day before Raymond Roth was pulled over , his wife , Evana , showed authorities e - mails she had discovered that appeared to detail a plan between him and his son to fake his death . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's admitted it now . He 's accepted responsibility . " On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . " He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July starts after Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence story: Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . " On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said .
