event: He accepted responsibility starts before Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: positive
event: He accepted responsibility starts after Davis added that his client has been under treatment for bipolar disorder in recent weeks story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth , 48 , of Massapequa , New York , was first reported missing in the waters off Jones Beach late last July by his 22-year - old son , Jonathan Roth . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Raymond Roth on Thursday agreed to plead guilty to the conspiracy charge in exchange for a sentence of 90 days in jail and five years ' probation , the district attorney 's office said . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . " There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . The son 's case is still pending , the district attorney said . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . " 	answer: negative
event: During plea negotiations Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time starts before Davis said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's admitted it now . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: During plea negotiations Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time starts after Davis said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Several days into an extensive search involving multiple agencies , New York State Park Police said , authorities learned the missing man was in South Carolina , where he had been pulled over for speeding . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . There needs to be a way for me to find out how things are going . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . Raymond Roth 's attorney , Brian Davis , denied in August that Roth had involved his son in the scheme . " He 's admitted it now . On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests , Davis said . He would like to straighten things out with ( Jonathan ) when the time comes , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: During plea negotiations Raymond Roth asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time starts before On the advice of both their attorneys , father and son have not been in contact since their arrests Davis said story: A New York man who was accused of faking his death last summer pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge Thursday , Nassau County District Attorney Kathleen Rice announced . Raymond Roth wanted his wife and son to collect at least $ 410,000 in life insurance benefits while he started a new life in Florida , Rice said . State police arrested both men in early August on charges of insurance fraud , conspiracy and filing a false report . He also must pay restitution for the cost of the search -- $ 27,445 to the U.S. Coast Guard and $ 9,109 to the Nassau County Police Department . Evana Roth told CNN in August she thought her husband devised the plan after he was fired from his job in July . Her attorney , Lenard Leeds , said she had been unaware of the ruse before she uncovered the e - mail correspondence . Call me Sunday night at 8 PM at the resort , " Raymond Roth wrote in an e - mail to his son the day before the son reported him missing . Jonathan Roth 's attorney , Joey Jackson , defended his client after his arrest , saying , " There was abuse here , manipulation here , coercion here " from the father . We had issues concerning the facts people had whether ( Roth ) had an agreement with his son , " Davis told CNN on Thursday . " He 's admitted it now . " During plea negotiations , Raymond Roth  asked the district attorney 's office not to give his son jail time , Davis said . 	answer: positive

event: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts before it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter story: The FAA on Friday  announced it will  close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts after it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter story: The FAA on Friday  announced it will  close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative

Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts after the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday  announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts after the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will  close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts before the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will  close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts before A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts --  sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter starts after A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts --  sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: expected to shutter starts before A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been  expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: expected to shutter starts after A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been  expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: expected to shutter starts before the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been  expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: expected to shutter starts after the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been  expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 starts after the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: positive
event: A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will begin on April 7 starts before the FAA said story: The FAA on Friday announced it will close 149 regional airport control towers because of forced spending cuts -- sparing 40 others that the FAA had been expected to shutter . A four - week , phased closure of the 149 control towers will  begin on April 7 , the FAA  said . The FAA had been expected to announce the closure of 189 low- or moderate - volume towers staffed by contractors . Before Friday 's announcement , it said it would consider keeping a tower open if the airport convinces the agency it is in the " national interest " to do so . By congressional mandate , the FAA must cut nearly $ 600 million from its nearly $ 48 billion budget this fiscal year . Because the majority of its 47,000 employees are air traffic controllers , it is impossible to cut its budget without affecting controllers , the agency says . 	answer: negative
event: Medical science advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment starts before No one knows what technology will be available in five years said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is  advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , "  said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: Medical science advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment starts after No one knows what technology will be available in five years said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is  advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , "  said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: Medical science advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment starts after Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011  removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: Medical science advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment starts before Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011  removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . event: No one knows what technology will be available in five years said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible starts after Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , "  said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011  removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: No one knows what technology will be available in five years said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible starts before Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts after a position he held for almost seven years story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts before a position he held for almost seven years story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts before His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was  forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts after His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was  forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts before Leon adding I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was  forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon ,  adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . 	answer: positive
event: Leon who early this year forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years starts after Leon adding I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was  forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon ,  adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . 	answer: negative
event: a position he held for almost seven years starts before His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had  held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: a position he held for almost seven years starts after His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had  held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative

event: a position he held for almost seven years starts after Leon adding I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had  held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon ,  adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand starts before Leon adding I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon ,  adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive
event: His thinking is no longer clear said Leon adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand starts after Leon adding I was making too many mistakes on the stand story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . Some seek escape in their careers , but that is no longer an option for Leon , who early this year was forced to step down as a juvenile probation officer in Travis County , Texas , a position he had held for almost seven years . His thinking is no longer clear ,  said Leon ,  adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . But Leon can still run . What has startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative
event: What startled the medical community even more starts after He won the Gusher Marathon finishing in 3:07:35 story: In competitions against the clock , some athletes display an ability to seize control . Think of the Clark - Kent - to - Superman routines that John Elway and Michael Jordan often pulled in the final seconds . But Iram Leon stands on the sidelines of his own race against time . Lodged in his brain is an untreatable and inoperable cancerous tumor that statistics suggest will kill him before he is 40 , eight years from now . Medical science is advancing at a rate that does n't preclude the development of a treatment , but it 's not clear if it will come in time . " No one knows what technology will be available in five years , " said Allan Friedman , Duke University Hospital neurosurgeon in chief , who in 2011 removed as much of Leon 's brain tumor as possible . The torment of enduring that wait can paste a cancer patient to the couch , a surrender heavily associated with deadlier outcomes . His thinking is no longer clear , said Leon , adding , " I was making too many mistakes on the stand . " But Leon can still run . Two years after his brain - cancer diagnosis , he recently ran a sub - five - minute mile for the first time since high school . What has  startled the medical community even more is what Leon did this month in Beaumont , Texas . He  won the Gusher Marathon , finishing in 3:07:35 . That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: positive

That was one second slower than his personal record in the 26.2-mile event , set days before he underwent brain surgery in early 2011 . 	answer: negative

event: documenting human rights abuses in Russia starts before The US embassy in Moscow voiced concern story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for  documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has  voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: documenting human rights abuses in Russia starts after The US embassy in Moscow voiced concern story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . event: A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying starts after the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law  says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying starts before the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law  says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - starts before Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive

Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative

event: the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - starts after inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - starts before inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: the label " foreign agents denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - starts after inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to  denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts after inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts before inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts after inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts before inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts after inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts before inspectors already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already  seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts before A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website  said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts after A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website  said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts after the inspections directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly  linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive
event: Memorial says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday starts before the inspections directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it story: Russian police and tax inspectors have raided the offices of the human rights group Memorial and other civil society groups which get foreign funding . Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial  says inspectors returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website said the inspections were directly  linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: negative

Memorial is famous for documenting human rights abuses in Russia . The US embassy in Moscow has voiced concern and asked the Russian government for an explanation . A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution . Memorial says inspectors  returned to its Moscow offices on Friday , having already seized 600 documents including accounts on Thursday . A statement on the Memorial website  said the inspections were directly linked to the new law on NGOs and the targeted groups ' compliance with it . Memorial director Arseny Roginsky , quoted by the Russian news website Vesti , said it was " a complete check on everything concerned with our sources of funding " . He insisted that the NGO law " will not change our position at all " . " We wo n't refuse foreign donations , nor will we register as a ' foreign agent ' , " he said . 	answer: positive

A new Russian law says foreign - funded non - governmental groups ( NGOs ) linked to politics must register as " foreign agents " - a term which suggests spying . In the worst repressions of the Soviet period the label " foreign agents " was used to denounce dissidents - or simply political rivals of Joseph Stalin - and could lead to execution .
