event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been  found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been  found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: negative
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been  found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been  found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: negative
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found  floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found  floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts before obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found  floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: More than 16,000 dead pigs floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai starts after obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found  floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: negative
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts before A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts after A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes  cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts before obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts after obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts before obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts after obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital ,  causing convulsive coughing and  obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts before top government officials forced to openly acknowledge them story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive

event: A haze akin to volcanic fumes causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City starts before top government officials forced to openly acknowledge them story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been  forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive

event: top government officials forced to openly acknowledge them starts before Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been  forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive

State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . event: top government officials forced to openly acknowledge them starts before she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been  forced to openly acknowledge them . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative

event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress ,  said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and  kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself story: A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress ,  said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and  kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after the air pollution made him " quite upset " story: So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before the air pollution made him " quite upset " story: So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress ,  said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress ,  said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she  checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive

More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . event: she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she  checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " " 	answer: positive
event: she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . event: she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and  kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and  kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: negative
event: she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: she kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up starts after the air pollution made him " quite upset " story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: positive
event: Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up starts before the air pollution made him " quite upset " story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " 	answer: negative
event: Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister ,  said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . " " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: the air pollution made him " quite upset " starts before Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: the air pollution made him " quite upset " starts after Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had  made him " quite upset " and  vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: Li Keqiang , the new prime minister said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up starts after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop .
