" China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said , calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: On Feb. 28 Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts before China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level the analysts said calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: On Feb. 28 Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts after China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level the analysts said calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . State - owned power companies have been similarly resistant . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . " The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: negative
event: On Feb. 28 Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts before the analysts calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . And as with the oil companies , the power companies exert an outsize influence over environmental policy debates . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . On Feb. 28 , Deutsche Bank  released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said ,  calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . The report estimated that the number of passenger cars in China was on track to hit 400 million by 2030 , up from 90 million now . 	answer: positive
event: On Feb. 28 Deutsche Bank released an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts after the analysts calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . event: an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts before China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level the analysts said calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . More than 16,000 dead pigs have been found floating in rivers that provide drinking water to Shanghai . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . Fu Ying , the spokeswoman for the National People 's Congress , said she checked for smog every morning after opening her curtains and kept at home face masks for her daughter and herself . event: an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts before the analysts calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said ,  calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . 	answer: positive
event: an analysts ' note saying that China 's current economic policies would result in an enormous surge in coal consumption and automobile sales over the next decade starts after the analysts calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups story: China 's state leadership transition has taken place this month against an ominous backdrop . A haze akin to volcanic fumes cloaked the capital , causing convulsive coughing and obscuring the portrait of Mao Zedong on the gate to the Forbidden City . So severe are China 's environmental woes , especially the noxious air , that top government officials have been forced to openly acknowledge them . Li Keqiang , the new prime minister , said the air pollution had made him " quite upset " and vowed to " show even greater resolve and make more vigorous efforts " to clean it up . Last month , after deadly air pollution hit record levels in northern China , officials led byWen Jiabao , then the prime minister , put forward strict new fuel standards that the oil companies had blocked for years . But there are doubts about whether the oil companies will comply , especially since oil officials resisted a similar government order for higher - grade fuel four years ago . The companies regularly ignore government orders to upgrade coal - burning electricity plants , according to ministry data . In 2011 , during a round of discussions over stricter emissions standards , the China Electricity Council , which represents the companies , pushed back hard against the proposals , saying that the costs of upgrading the plants would be too high . China 's air pollution will become a lot worse from the already unbearable level , " the analysts said ,  calling for drastic policy changes and " a strong government will to overcome the opposition from interest groups . 	answer: negative
event: the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 starts before George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side story: The last surviving member of the team which first  conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 starts after George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side story: The last surviving member of the team which first  conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 died in a Derbyshire nursing home starts before George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side story: George Lowe , 89 ,  died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 died in a Derbyshire nursing home starts after George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side story: George Lowe , 89 ,  died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side starts after the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that  helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness with his wife Mary by his side starts before the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that  helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 starts before Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that  helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones  paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . " " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 starts after Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that  helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones  paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . " " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 starts before a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who  shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 starts after a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who  shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: negative
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts after a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts before a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts after Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones  paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also  took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts before Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones  paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also  took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: negative
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts after the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . It had a multiplying effect . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight starts before the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . It had a multiplying effect . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight starts after Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Mr Lowe also  took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . 	answer: positive
event: a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight starts before Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Mr Lowe also  took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . 	answer: negative
event: a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight starts after the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who  shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which  made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: a " gentle soul and fine climber who shunned the limelight starts before the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who  shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which  made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole starts before the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole starts after the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . event: Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole starts before He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also  took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive

event: the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole starts before He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which  made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole starts after He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which  made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia starts before Speaking to the BBC in 1995 Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe  said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia starts after Speaking to the BBC in 1995 Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe  said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia starts after We estimated we could do it in 100 days story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We  estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia starts before We estimated we could do it in 100 days story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later  made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We  estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative

We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. event: We estimated we could do it in 100 days starts before we got across on the 99th day story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . event: We estimated we could do it in 100 days starts after we got across on the 99th day story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: It had a multiplying effect starts after England and New Zealand knew about it story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand  knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: It had a multiplying effect starts before England and New Zealand knew about it story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand  knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: It had a multiplying effect starts before we thought that 's where it would stop story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we  thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: It had a multiplying effect starts after we thought that 's where it would stop story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we  thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: England and New Zealand knew about it starts before we thought that 's where it would stop story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: England and New Zealand knew about it starts after we thought that 's where it would stop story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: England and New Zealand knew about it starts before He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand  knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also  talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: England and New Zealand knew about it starts after He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand  knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also  talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: England and New Zealand knew about it starts before He wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand  knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to  wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
