event: we thought that 's where it would stop starts after He wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we  thought that 's where it would stop . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: we thought that 's where it would stop starts before He wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we  thought that 's where it would stop . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera starts after He wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera starts before He wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: he said starts after the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he  said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: he said starts before the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he  said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: he said starts after called him a " hero " story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he  said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 ,  called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: he said starts before called him a " hero " story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he  said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 ,  called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 starts before called him a " hero " story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 starts after called him a " hero " story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: negative
event: the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 starts before but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " 	answer: positive
event: the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 starts after but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first  met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " 	answer: negative
event: called him a " hero " starts before but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 ,  called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: called him a " hero " starts after but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 ,  called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said starts after he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he  worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said starts before he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he  said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he  worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said starts before A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , published in May. story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: but then it is not very often that you get to meet one he said starts after A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , published in May. story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " " " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones starts before A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , published in May. story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones starts after A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , published in May. story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He said Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . event: He said Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition starts after He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He  said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He said Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition starts before He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " " he said . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He  said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He said Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition starts after He remained a humble , happy man right to the end story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He said Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition starts before He remained a humble , happy man right to the end story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century starts before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before  retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century starts after retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. " He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before  retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century starts after Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . " " Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe  worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive

" " Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . event: He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century starts before he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century starts after he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was  involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before  retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts after retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe story: New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " Before  retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts after Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe  worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts before Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences story: George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe  worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts before he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: He remained a humble , happy man right to the end starts after he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . " It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet  remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: negative
event: retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe starts after Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: positive
event: retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe starts before Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences story: Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . A book of memoirs and photographs from the climb by Mr Lowe , which he worked on with Dr Lewis - Jones , is due to be published in May. He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June . 	answer: negative
event: retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe starts before he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . " 	answer: positive
event: retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe starts after he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . Family friend and historian Dr Huw Lewis - Jones paid tribute to a " gentle soul and fine climber " who shunned the limelight . He later made expeditions to Greenland , Greece and Ethiopia . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . He said : " Lowe was a brilliant , kind fellow who never sought the limelight ... and 60 years on from Everest his achievements deserve wider recognition . event: Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences starts before he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe  worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: positive
event: Before retiring in 1984 Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences starts after he leaves three sons from a previous marriage story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . There was a great feeling of euphoria from everyone . It had a multiplying effect . " We were pleased that England and New Zealand knew about it , and we thought that 's where it would stop . " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? I do n't often use that word but then it is not very often that you get to meet one , " he said . " He was involved in two of the most important explorations of the 20th Century ... yet remained a humble , happy man right to the end ... an inspirational lesson to us all . Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe  worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . 	answer: negative

event: he leaves three sons from a previous marriage starts before The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . George Lowe , 89 , died in Ripley on Wednesday after a long - term illness , with his wife Mary by his side . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . Speaking to the BBC in 1995 , Mr Lowe said of his Antarctic adventure : " We estimated we could do it in 100 days , and we got across on the 99th day . It had a multiplying effect . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . Dr Lewis - Jones , the former curator at the Scott Polar Research Institute at the University of Cambridge , who first met Mr Lowe in 2005 , called him a " hero " . " I do n't often use that word " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott ,  died last June . 	answer: positive
event: he leaves three sons from a previous marriage starts after The last British climbing member of the 1953 team , Mike Westmacott , died last June story: The last surviving member of the team which first conquered Everest in 1953 has died in a Derbyshire nursing home . New Zealand - born Mr Lowe was part of the team that helped Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay to the summit in 1953 . Mr Lowe also took part in the trans - Antarctic expedition of 1957 - 58 , which made the first successful overland crossing of Antarctica via the South Pole . " " He also talked about his " second job " as the group 's cameraman , and having to wear four pairs of gloves to work the clockwork camera . " When there were dramas , there was a split problem . Do you take part in the urgency - or do you record it ? " he said . " I do n't often use that word " " Before retiring in 1984 , Mr Lowe worked as an Inspector of Schools with the Department of Education and Sciences , and he  leaves three sons from a previous marriage . event: her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress starts after An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home story: An hour before her colleagues  gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte  slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . The desks , he sternly told her , were for senators only . " " But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . " " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand , Democrat of New York , and Senator Susan Collins , Republican of Maine , led the repeal in the Senate of " do n't ask , do n't tell " in 2010 , allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the military . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party and voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: positive

event: her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress starts after the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state cast their votes story: Ms. Ayotte 's induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation 's political class , female senators , had begun . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . Senator Barbara Boxer , the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee , shepherded the highway bill . We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party and voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: positive
event: her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress starts before the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state cast their votes story: Ms. Ayotte 's induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation 's political class , female senators , had begun . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . Senator Barbara Boxer , the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee , shepherded the highway bill . We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . event: her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress starts before As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes a doorman marched toward her with purpose story: An hour before her colleagues  gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes , a doorman  marched toward her with purpose . The desks , he sternly told her , were for senators only . " A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . For the first time there is a woman - Senator Barbara A. Mikulski , a Maryland Democrat - in charge of the Senate Appropriations Committee , which dispenses billions of dollars annually throughout the government and has long been particularly dominated by men . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . One of the biggest bills to pass the Senate last year was farm legislation led by Senator Debbie Stabenow , a Michigan Democrat who presides over the agriculture committee . " " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand , Democrat of New York , and Senator Susan Collins , Republican of Maine , led the repeal in the Senate of " do n't ask , do n't tell " in 2010 , allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the military . 	answer: positive
event: her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress starts after As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes a doorman marched toward her with purpose story: An hour before her colleagues  gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . event: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home starts before Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte  slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire ,  sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes , a doorman marched toward her with purpose . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia became the first woman in the United States Senate - sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women remain an anomaly in the upper chamber . But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . " " Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . 	answer: positive
event: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home starts after Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte  slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire ,  sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes , a doorman marched toward her with purpose . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia became the first woman in the United States Senate - sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women remain an anomaly in the upper chamber . But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . " " Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . 	answer: negative
event: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home starts after the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state cast their votes story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte  slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had  cast their votes , a doorman marched toward her with purpose . The desks , he sternly told her , were for senators only . " " " But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . One of the biggest bills to pass the Senate last year was farm legislation led by Senator Debbie Stabenow , a Michigan Democrat who presides over the agriculture committee . " We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . 	answer: positive
