event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party starts before This year all four of the female Senate Republicans voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . Ms. Ayotte 's induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation 's political class , female senators , had begun . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " There still just are n't that many of us . Senator Barbara Boxer , the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee , shepherded the highway bill . " We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand , Democrat of New York , and Senator Susan Collins , Republican of Maine , led the repeal in the Senate of " do n't ask , do n't tell " in 2010 , allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the military . 	answer: positive
event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party starts after This year all four of the female Senate Republicans voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . Ms. Ayotte 's induction that January day in 2011 into the most rarefied ranks of the nation 's political class , female senators , had begun . The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " There still just are n't that many of us . Senator Barbara Boxer , the California Democrat who is chairwoman of the Environment and Public Works Committee , shepherded the highway bill . " We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " Just as important , even male senators say , is the potential the women hold for changing the tenor of the Senate and pushing for compromise in the highly partisan atmosphere on Capitol Hill . " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand , Democrat of New York , and Senator Susan Collins , Republican of Maine , led the repeal in the Senate of " do n't ask , do n't tell " in 2010 , allowing gay men and women to serve openly in the military . 	answer: negative
event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party starts after the Violence Against Women Act which lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes , a doorman marched toward her with purpose . " The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia became the first woman in the United States Senate - sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women remain an anomaly in the upper chamber . But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans  split with their party and voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had  lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: positive
event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party starts before the Violence Against Women Act which lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . As Ms. Ayotte , a freshman Republican from New Hampshire , sat down at the wooden desk where generations of lawmakers from her state had cast their votes , a doorman marched toward her with purpose . " The desk thing really stuck with me , " Ms. Ayotte said . " In the 90 years since Rebecca Felton of Georgia became the first woman in the United States Senate - sworn in for a mere 24 hours - women remain an anomaly in the upper chamber . But with 20 female senators now in office , an all - time high , women have morphed from the curiosity they were for much of the 20th century into an important new force on key committees and legislation . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . Senator Patty Murray , a Washington Democrat , is the first chairwoman of the Budget Committee and is charged with shaping the Democratic strategy in the fiscal battle dominating Capitol Hill . " But more importantly , we are growing in our power . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans  split with their party and voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had  lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: negative
event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress starts after the Violence Against Women Act which lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . The desks , he sternly told her , were for senators only . " " There still just are n't that many of us . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . For the first time there is a woman - Senator Barbara A. Mikulski , a Maryland Democrat - in charge of the Senate Appropriations Committee , which dispenses billions of dollars annually throughout the government and has long been particularly dominated by men . One of the biggest bills to pass the Senate last year was farm legislation led by Senator Debbie Stabenow , a Michigan Democrat who presides over the agriculture committee . We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party and  voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had  lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: positive
event: This year all four of the female Senate Republicans voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had lapsed during the last Congress starts before the Violence Against Women Act which lapsed during the last Congress story: An hour before her colleagues gathered for their first vote of a new Congress , Senator Kelly Ayotte slipped into an empty Senate chamber to savor the grandeur of her legislative home . The desks , he sternly told her , were for senators only . " " There still just are n't that many of us . A record nine women now lead committees , including some of the most powerful ones . For the first time there is a woman - Senator Barbara A. Mikulski , a Maryland Democrat - in charge of the Senate Appropriations Committee , which dispenses billions of dollars annually throughout the government and has long been particularly dominated by men . One of the biggest bills to pass the Senate last year was farm legislation led by Senator Debbie Stabenow , a Michigan Democrat who presides over the agriculture committee . We are growing in number , " said Senator Amy Klobuchar , Democrat of Minnesota . When I first started just six years ago , it was unusual to have a woman managing a bill . " " So I think it 's going to have , and is having , a positive impact on the Senate . " While partisan division is the central characteristic of the modern Congress , women have begun to crack away at the gridlock by forming coalitions that have surprised leaders of both parties . This year , all four of the female Senate Republicans split with their party and  voted with Senate Democrats to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act , which had  lapsed during the last Congress . 	answer: negative
event: the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost starts before The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration  says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive
event: the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost starts after The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration  says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: negative
event: the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost starts before The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration  says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive
event: the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost starts after The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration  says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: negative
event: The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower starts before The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services  says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive
event: The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower starts after The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services  says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . event: The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower starts after a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services  says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that  says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive

event: The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower starts after a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that  says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive

event: The Department of Health and Human Services pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower starts before The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , "  pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections  suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . 	answer: positive

That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive

event: The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be starts before Carriers will filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections  suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be  filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . 	answer: positive
event: The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be starts after Carriers will filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections  suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . 	answer: negative
event: Carriers will filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months starts after Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be  filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . 	answer: positive
event: Carriers will filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months starts before Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The projected increases are at odds with what the Obama Administration says consumers should be expecting overall in terms of cost . event: Many consumers will getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law starts before The effects of the law will vary widely story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be  getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive
event: Many consumers will getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law starts after The effects of the law will vary widely story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . Carriers will be filing proposed prices with regulators over the next few months . Part of the murkiness stems from the role of government subsidies . Federal subsidies under the health law will help lower - income consumers defray costs , but they are generally not included in insurers ' premium projections . Many consumers will be  getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts  agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive

event: insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down starts before Starting next year the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts  agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will  block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . The rules can also affect small businesses , which sometimes pay premiums tied to employees ' health status and claims history . 	answer: positive
event: insurers and other analysts agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down starts after Starting next year the law will block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories story: Health insurers are privately warning brokers that premiums for many individuals and small businesses could increase sharply next year because of the health - care overhaul law , with the nation 's biggest firm projecting that rates could more than double for some consumers buying their own plans . The projections , made in sessions with brokers and agents , provide some of the most concrete evidence yet of how much insurance companies might increase prices when major provisions of the law kick in next year - a subject of rigorous debate . The Department of Health and Human Services says that the law will " make health - care coverage more affordable and accessible , " pointing to a 2009 analysis by the Congressional Budget Office that says average individual premiums , on an apples - to - apples basis , would be lower . The gulf between the pricing talk from some insurers and the government projections suggests how complicated the law 's effects will be . Many consumers will be getting more generous plans because of new requirements in the law . The effects of the law will vary widely , and insurers and other analysts  agree that some consumers and small businesses will likely see premiums go down . Starting next year , the law will  block insurers from refusing to sell coverage or setting premiums based on people 's health histories , and will reduce their ability to set rates based on age . That can raise coverage prices for younger , healthier consumers , while reining them in for older , sicker ones . event: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries starts before President Barack Obama wrapped his first presidential visit to Israel story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu  apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama  wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries starts after President Barack Obama wrapped his first presidential visit to Israel story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu  apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries starts before seemed to yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu  apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries starts after seemed to yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu  apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts before President Barack Obama wrapped his first presidential visit to Israel story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: positive
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts after President Barack Obama wrapped his first presidential visit to Israel story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts before seemed to yield few concrete steps story: The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: positive
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts after seemed to yield few concrete steps story: The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts before that yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to  yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts after that yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to  yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: seemed to yield few concrete steps starts after that yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: seemed to yield few concrete steps starts before that yield few concrete steps story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts before Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive

event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts before the Israeli leader in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , "  agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: The call which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel starts after the Israeli leader in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which  happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , "  agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative

" Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . event: President Barack Obama wrapped his first presidential visit to Israel starts before the Israeli leader in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama  wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive

event: seemed to yield few concrete steps starts before the Israeli leader in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , "  agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: seemed to yield few concrete steps starts after the Israeli leader in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that  seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , "  agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: that yield few concrete steps starts before Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to  yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office  confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: that yield few concrete steps starts after Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to  yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office  confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations .
