He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life starts before Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life starts after Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life starts after what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu  apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life starts before what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu  apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu agreed to complete the agreement on compensation starts before Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and  agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu agreed to complete the agreement on compensation starts after Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and  agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu agreed to complete the agreement on compensation starts after what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and  agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors Prime Minister Netanyahu agreed to complete the agreement on compensation starts before what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and  agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation the statement said starts after Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement  said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation the statement said starts before Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement  said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation the statement said starts after what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement  said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation the statement said starts before what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement  said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts after what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts before what happened on board the Mavi Marmara story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what  happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts before Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: positive
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts after Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts after he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: positive
event: Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life according to the statement starts before he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu  told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: what happened on board the Mavi Marmara starts before Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: what happened on board the Mavi Marmara starts after Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: what happened on board the Mavi Marmara starts before he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: what happened on board the Mavi Marmara starts after he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations starts after he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations starts before he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative

He said he  discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . event: Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations starts after they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader story: The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama  said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they  agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive

He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they  agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had  spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he  discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations starts before they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they  agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: he spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations starts after they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they  agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . event: he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week starts before they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: positive
event: he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week starts after they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan accepted the Israeli apology , the prime minister 's office said . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials said . 	answer: negative
event: he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week starts before The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week officials said story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he  discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials  said . 	answer: positive
event: he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week starts after The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week officials said story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . " In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Netanyahu told Mr. Erdogan that what happened on board the Mavi Marmara was " unintentional and Israel expresses regret over injuries and loss of life , " according to the statement . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he  discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week , officials  said . 	answer: negative
event: they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader starts before The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week officials said story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . event: they agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader starts after The incident was a subject of talks between Mr. Netanyahu and President Barack Obama during the president 's trip to Israel this week officials said story: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized on Friday to Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan for a raid on a Turkish flotilla ship , a move that will help restore strained ties between the countries . The call , which happened as President Barack Obama wrapped up his first presidential visit to Israel , was an unexpected outcome from a Mideast trip that seemed to yield few concrete steps . Mr. Netanyahu 's office confirmed that the Israeli leader , in a conversation with Mr. Erdogan , " agreed to restore normalization between Israel and Turkey , including the dispatch of ambassadors and the cancellation of legal steps against [ Israeli Defense Forces ] soldiers . " Mr. Erdogan has long sought an apology for the raid in May 2010 on the Mavi Marmara , which was part of a flotilla that sought to break Israel 's blockade of Gaza . An Israeli raid on the ship left nine passengers dead , all of them Turkish or of Turkish descent . In light of the Israeli investigation into the incident , which pointed out several operational errors , Prime Minister Netanyahu apologized to the Turkish people for any errors that could have led to loss of life and agreed to complete the agreement on compensation , " the statement said . Mr. Obama said later at a news conference in Amman that he had spoken to both leaders over the past two years about how it was in the interests of both countries to restore normal relations . He said he discussed the issue with Mr. Netanyahu during his visit to Israel this week , and that they  agreed the timing was good for a discussion with the Turkish leader . 	answer: negative
event: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse starts before And that economists and investors contend is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks story: Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse starts after And that economists and investors contend is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks story: Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: the havoc that Greece would created had it not been bailed out starts before And that economists and investors contend is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " " This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . 	answer: positive

event: And that economists and investors contend is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks starts after depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . And that , economists and investors  contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian -  contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . " This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . " " " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive

From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . " This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . event: And that economists and investors contend is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks starts after Cyprus which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which  creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . " " By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
