" " By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: Only Ireland still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 starts before As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . " " By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " 	answer: positive
event: Only Ireland still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 starts after As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . " " By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " 	answer: negative
event: debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them starts before As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . " " This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them starts after As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . " " This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them starts before There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , "  said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . 	answer: positive
event: debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them starts after There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , "  said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . 	answer: negative
event: As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run starts before There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is  forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , "  said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . 	answer: positive
event: As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them the view forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run starts after There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is  forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , "  said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . 	answer: negative
event: There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London starts before This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . 	answer: positive
event: There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London starts after This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . 	answer: negative
event: There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London starts after the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction  touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London starts before the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction  touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts after he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " This is not a Lehman , " he  said ,  referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . " " " " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: positive
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts before he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " This is not a Lehman , " he  said ,  referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . " " " " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: negative
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts after the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts before the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts after the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . " This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts before the disastrous chain reaction touched by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . " This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts after a French economist who studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . This is not a Lehman , " he  said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Eric Dor is a French economist who has  studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . So when the president of Cyprus admitted this week that his country did not have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - a crucial bond of trust between a government and its citizens was snapped . 	answer: positive
event: This is not a Lehman he said referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts before a French economist who studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . This is not a Lehman , " he  said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Eric Dor is a French economist who has  studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . So when the president of Cyprus admitted this week that his country did not have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - a crucial bond of trust between a government and its citizens was snapped . 	answer: negative
event: he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts after a French economist who studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " This is not a Lehman , " he said ,  referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: positive
event: he referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 starts before a French economist who studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " This is not a Lehman , " he said ,  referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: negative
event: This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus starts before This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: positive
event: This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus starts after This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . 	answer: negative
event: This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France starts after They saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke story: the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . " Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive

" Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: They saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke starts before Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . " " Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive

event: Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse starts after the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . That is a mere rounding error compared with the euro zone G.D.P. of 9.4 trillion euros . " Mr. Dor  notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was  put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . So when the president of Cyprus admitted this week that his country did not have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - a crucial bond of trust between a government and its citizens was snapped . " 	answer: positive

event: when the president of Cyprus admitted this week that his country did not have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - starts before It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee Mr. Dor said story: ut for the broader financial system in Europe , And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . From a financial standpoint , what is most noteworthy is that the combined debt of the Cypriot people , companies and government is 2.6 times the size of the country 's gross domestic product . Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . " By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . So when the president of Cyprus  admitted this week that his country did not have the money to backstop the 30 billion euros of guaranteed bank deposits - a figure greater than the Cypriot economy itself - a crucial bond of trust between a government and its citizens was snapped . It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor  said . 	answer: positive

event: admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee starts before admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee Mr. Dor said story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has  admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor  said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: positive
event: admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee starts after admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee Mr. Dor said story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . Greece may well have been too big to fail last year , but Cyprus , which creates less than one - half percent of the euro zone 's gross domestic product , is certainly not . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . " " Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . This explains why Germany and others are putting so much pressure on Cyprus , " said Mr. Dor , head of research at the Ieseg School of Management in Lille , France . They are saying we can take the risk of pushing Cyprus out of the euro zone , and that Europe can take the losses without going broke . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has  admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee , " Mr. Dor  said . A hasty expulsion from the euro zone would make the savings of the Cypriot people all the more evanescent , once they are converted back into Cypriot pounds , the currency Cyprus used before adopting the euro in 2007 . 	answer: negative
event: admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee starts after Cyprus adopting the euro in 2007 story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . " There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , " said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has 	answer: positive
event: admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee starts before Cyprus adopting the euro in 2007 story: And for European unity and diplomacy , the Cyprus debacle has already been at least a short - term disaster . the losses resulting from a Cypriot banking collapse and the country 's return to its former currency would be minimal compared with the havoc that Greece would have created had it not been bailed out . And that , economists and investors contend , is why Germany and its Dutch stalking horse , Jeroen Dijsselbloem , the president of the Eurogroup of finance ministers , were so adamant that depositors - large and small , Cypriot and Russian - contribute 5.8 billion euros ( $ 7.5 billion ) toward the 10 billion euro bailout of Cyprus 's largest banks . " There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , " said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . This is not a Lehman , " he said , referring to the disastrous chain reaction touched off by the collapse of Lehman Brothers in 2008 . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . Estimates of the potential cost if Greece had been forced into a disorderly euro exit have ranged from 200 billion euros to 800 billion euros , given the larger exposure that the European Central Bank and European banks had to the country . Those deposits are supposed to be insured by national governments . " It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has 	answer: negative
event: It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee Mr. Dor said starts after Cyprus adopting the euro in 2007 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , " said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . 	answer: positive
event: It is the first time ever that the leader of a euro zone country has admitted that he could not afford to pay the guarantee Mr. Dor said starts before Cyprus adopting the euro in 2007 story: A Cyprus exit from the euro union , if it comes to that , would have a devastating effect on the country 's citizens , who are among the most indebted in the euro zone . ut for the broader financial system in Europe , Only Ireland , still struggling to recover from the banking collapse that required an international bailout in 2010 , has a higher debt - to - G.D.P. ratio among euro zone countries . As debts in Europe mount in inverse proportion to the ability of its citizens , companies and governments to make good on them , the view is forming in Berlin and Brussels that a signal must be sent that citizens and investors must start accepting losses for the euro zone to survive in the long run . There have been too many bailouts in Europe ; it 's time to remove the air bags , " said Stephen Jen , a former economist at the International Monetary Fund who runs a hedge fund in London . Eric Dor is a French economist who has studied the mechanics of how a country might remove itself from the monetary union . By his calculations , the euro zone - through its central banking system and its national banks - has just 27 billion euros in outstanding credit exposure to Cyprus . " " Mr. Dor notes that the current euro zonewide system of insuring bank deposits up to 100,000 euros was put in place after the financial panic that followed the Lehman collapse . 	answer: negative
event: Heavy snow causing disruption to transport across the UK with heavy rainfall bringing flooding to the south - west of England starts after heavy rainfall bringing flooding to the south - west of England story: Heavy snow is  causing disruption to transport across the UK , with heavy rainfall  bringing flooding to the south - west of England . Rescuers searching for a woman trapped in a landslide at her home in Looe , Cornwall , said they had found a body . Over 200,000 Belfast customers were affected by a blackout but power is starting to be restored . Northern Ireland 's World Cup qualifier with Russia has been postponed until 15:00 GMT Saturday due to heavy snow . There are 12 flood warnings in the South West , with Met Office warnings for snow covering much of the UK . This comes just over a week before the start of British Summer Time . BBC forecasters said the snow would cause travel disruption across northern parts of the UK on Friday , with some 20cm-40 cm ( 8in-16 in ) falling in places . Atrocious conditions could be expected on high ground , they said . Roads in northern parts of Wales , the Midlands into the Pennines , southern Scotland and Northern Ireland would be the worst affected , while gale force winds would blow snow and drifts across trans - Pennine routes , they added . 	answer: positive

event: a woman trapped in a landslide at her home in Looe , Cornwall starts before they found a body story: Heavy snow is causing disruption to transport across the UK , with heavy rainfall bringing flooding to the south - west of England . Rescuers searching for a woman  trapped in a landslide at her home in Looe , Cornwall , said they had  found a body . Over 200,000 Belfast customers were affected by a blackout but power is starting to be restored . Northern Ireland 's World Cup qualifier with Russia has been postponed until 15:00 GMT Saturday due to heavy snow . There are 12 flood warnings in the South West , with Met Office warnings for snow covering much of the UK . This comes just over a week before the start of British Summer Time . BBC forecasters said the snow would cause travel disruption across northern parts of the UK on Friday , with some 20cm-40 cm ( 8in-16 in ) falling in places . Atrocious conditions could be expected on high ground , they said . Roads in northern parts of Wales , the Midlands into the Pennines , southern Scotland and Northern Ireland would be the worst affected , while gale force winds would blow snow and drifts across trans - Pennine routes , they added . 	answer: positive

Over 200,000 Belfast customers were affected by a blackout but power is  starting to be  restored . Northern Ireland 's World Cup qualifier with Russia has been postponed until 15:00 GMT Saturday due to heavy snow . There are 12 flood warnings in the South West , with Met Office warnings for snow covering much of the UK . This comes just over a week before the start of British Summer Time . BBC forecasters said the snow would cause travel disruption across northern parts of the UK on Friday , with some 20cm-40 cm ( 8in-16 in ) falling in places . Atrocious conditions could be expected on high ground , they said . Roads in northern parts of Wales , the Midlands into the Pennines , southern Scotland and Northern Ireland would be the worst affected , while gale force winds would blow snow and drifts across trans - Pennine routes , they added . 	answer: positive
event: power starting to be restored starts after power restored story: Heavy snow is causing disruption to transport across the UK , with heavy rainfall bringing flooding to the south - west of England . Rescuers searching for a woman trapped in a landslide at her home in Looe , Cornwall , said they had found a body . Over 200,000 Belfast customers were affected by a blackout but power is  starting to be  restored . Northern Ireland 's World Cup qualifier with Russia has been postponed until 15:00 GMT Saturday due to heavy snow . There are 12 flood warnings in the South West , with Met Office warnings for snow covering much of the UK . This comes just over a week before the start of British Summer Time . BBC forecasters said the snow would cause travel disruption across northern parts of the UK on Friday , with some 20cm-40 cm ( 8in-16 in ) falling in places . Atrocious conditions could be expected on high ground , they said . Roads in northern parts of Wales , the Midlands into the Pennines , southern Scotland and Northern Ireland would be the worst affected , while gale force winds would blow snow and drifts across trans - Pennine routes , they added . 	answer: negative

event: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy informed Thursday that he would face a formal investigation into whether he abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt , 90 , the heiress to the L'Oreal fortune and France 's richest woman , to get funds for his 2007 presidential campaign starts after he abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt , 90 , the heiress to the L'Oreal fortune and France 's richest woman to get funds for his 2007 presidential campaign story: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was  informed Thursday that he would face a formal investigation into whether he  abused the frailty of Liliane Bettencourt , 90 , the heiress to the L'Oreal fortune and France 's richest woman , to get funds for his 2007 presidential campaign . Mr. Sarkozy has denied accepting illegal campaign funds from Ms. Bettencourt , either personally or through his party treasurer at the time , Eric Woerth , as alleged by her former butler . Mr. Sarkozy 's lawyer , Thierry Herzog , called the judge 's decision , which indicates that the judge believes that Mr. Sarkozy probably committed a crime , " incoherent " and " unjust . " The lawyer said he would appeal . The ruling does not necessarily mean that Mr. Sarkozy , who lost his re - election bid last May and with it his presidential immunity from prosecution , will stand trial . 	answer: positive
